iti110:0.3: The Chapter on the Holy Offering of the Teaching
iti110:1.1: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.
iti110:2.1: “Mendicants, suppose a mendicant has a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought while walking.
iti110:2.2: They tolerate it and don’t give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it. Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when walking.
iti110:3.1: Suppose a mendicant has a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought while standing …
iti110:5.1: or when lying down while awake.
iti110:5.2: They tolerate it and don’t give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it. Such a mendicant is said to be ‘not keen or prudent, always lazy, and lacking energy’ when lying down while awake.
iti110:6.1: Suppose a mendicant has a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought while walking.
iti110:6.2: They don’t tolerate them, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
iti110:6.3: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘keen and prudent, always energetic and determined’ when walking.
iti110:7.1: Suppose a mendicant has a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought while standing …
iti110:9.1: or when lying down while awake.
iti110:9.2: They don’t tolerate it, but give it up, get rid of it, eliminate it, and obliterate it.
iti110:9.3: Such a mendicant is said to be ‘keen and prudent, always energetic and determined’ when lying down while awake.”
iti110:9.4: That is what the Buddha said.
